metadata.title: Insulating Property of Polypropylene Nanocomposites Filled with Nano-MgO of Different Concentration

sections.text: Index Terms - PP, Nano-MgO, TEM, DSC, breakdown strengths, space charge, dielectric property.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
TRADITIONAL cable insulation materials crosslinked polyethylene (XLPE) have been facing problems of low productive efficiency, energy-wasting and difficulty in waste recycle, which are not advocated in this energy-saving and environmental protection world. So the study and development of not-crosslinked materials used for cable insulation has an important significance. Polypropylene (PP) provides good performs on electric insulating property. Its electrical properties are nearly not influenced by environmental humidity and the frequency. PP has excellent heat-resistance which can make it usable for a long time under 373 K, and it also has excellent chemical-resistance, so PP could be a new research field in cable insulation materials.
Nanometer-sized particles exhibit novel properties for their length scale and high specific surface area as compared with bulk materials [1]. It was already clarified that the addition of nano-fillers such as layered silicate or chemical additives for electrical insulation would show improved electrical
performances with respect to the corresponding conventional materials [2-3]. It has been reported in some literature that the properties of breakdown strength, space charge behavior and partial discharge (PD) resistance are improved [4-7]. It was found that the dielectric strength of EVA and PP increased and space charge accumulation rate decreased with the increase in the content of organophilic nano-silicate [8]. Some research has been carried out to compare nano-fillers and micro-fillers and found the nano-micro-composite is higher in both breakdown strength and partial discharge resistance than the micro-composite in Al2O3/epoxy composite [9-10]. The nanocomposite including more than 0.5 phr shows a superior property to prevent the injection of space charge into bulk in MgO/LDPE nanocomposites [11]. It has been found that surface modification in XLPE/SiO2 could improve dc breakdown strength under different temperatures compared to XLPE or unmodified XLPE/SiO2 nanocomposites [12].
In this paper, different mass concentration of nano-MgO was added to PP, and the nano inorganic particles were treated by chemical method with coupling agent. Some experiments were carried out to investigate the microstructure, thermal analysis and dielectric property of MgO/PP nanocomposites. Manuscript received on 26 April 2016, in final form 13 July 2016, accepted 31 July 2016.
DOI: 10.1109/TDEI.2017.006015
Influences of the concentration of nano-filler in composite would be studied.

sections.heading: 2 EXPERIMENTAL METHODS
sections.text: Five kinds of nanocomposites with different nanofiller concentration were prepared, which was neat polypropylene (PP), 0.5 wt% nano MgO/PP composite, 1 wt% nano MgO/PP composite, 3 wt% nano MgO/PP composite and 6 wt% nano MgO/PP composite respectively. The investigations of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and differential scanning differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were carried out to observe the micro and morphological structure of composites, dc breakdown strengths test and space charge measurement were investigated to study the insulation property of nano MgO/PP composites.

sections.heading: 2.1 SAMPLE PREPARATION
sections.text: Nano particles of MgO were added to 95 % ethanol/water solution with the addition of coupling agent of Aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) [13-14], in order to reduce agglomeration of particles in nanoparticles. The intermixture of particles, coupling agent and ethanol/water solution was dispersed by ultrasonic wave for 2 h. The isotactic polypropylene (i-PP) was the liquid-phase propylene with melt index of 3.0 g/10min and isotacticity of more than 96 %. The mixture of i-PP and nano-MgO was stirred by a double screw mixer at 463 K for 15 min. Five kinds of specimens with different nanofiller concentration were pressed in mold by plate vulcanizing machine under the temperature of 463 K, and cooled down to room temperature at a constant pressure and cooling rate of 0.1 K/min.

sections.heading: 2.2 TEM TEST
sections.text: The composites with nano-MgO concentration of 0.5 wt% and 3 wt% were chosen for the investigation of transmission electron microscopy (TEM), which represent low concentration of nano loading and high concentration of nano loading, respectively. A slice about 100 nm was made by ultramicrotome (Leica UC6, from Germany), and it was observed by 120 kV transmission electron microscopy (Tecnai G2 spirit Biotwin, from America). The specific parameter profiles were 120 kV, 0.49 nm, 0.34 nm for the accelerating voltage, the dot resolution and linear resolution, respectively. The image of the nano particle was captured by the CCD camera (Gatan 832).

sections.heading: 2.3 DSC TEST
sections.text: The calorimetric experiments were performed in 204 F1 DSC from Netzsch in Germany. The experiments’ processes are showed as follows: Heating the temperature from 293 K to 483 K at the heating rate of 10 K/min, keeping the temperature of 483 K for 5 min, and cooling it to 293 K at the cooling rate of 10 K/min. In this way, the thermal history was eliminated. The testing progress was repeating of the above heating and cooling program, and the DSC testing data were record by a terminal computer.

sections.heading: 2.4 BREAKDOWN STRENGTHS TEST
sections.text: Breakdown strengths under DC voltage were investigated. The sample of 0.1 mm in thickness was inserted in sphere to sphere electrodes system. The diameter of the sphere electrode is 20 mm and the voltage increment rate is 2 kV/s. The schematic diagram of DC breakdown circuit was shown in Figure 1a, resistor R in the circuit represents the current limiting resistor and its value is about 300 kΩ; Capacitor C represents filtering capacitor and its value is about 0.05 F. The electrode system was shown in Figure 1b and the whole system was immersed in silicone oil. Ten valid measurement data was obtained so the accurate breakdown strengths data could be calculated.

sections.heading: 2.5 SPACE CHARGE TEST
sections.text: Space charge distribution in samples was measured by pulse electro-acoustic (PEA) method. The deconvolution of frequency domain was used to the data processing of space charge signal. The test system was an automatic test platform, which includes electrode system, high voltage pulse source， HVDC source，oscilloscope and so on. The upper electrode of the electrode system was semiconductor and the bottom electrode was aluminum. The samples of 0.3 mm in thickness were pre-polarized by applying the electrical field of 10 kV/mm, 30 kV/mm and 50 kV/mm for 30 min, respectively. The depolarization process of 30 mins short circuit was recorded after every pre-polarizing process.

sections.heading: 2.6 DIELECTRIC TEST
sections.text:
Dielectric tests were carried out to investigate relative dielectric constant r and dielectric loss tan of all the samples in a high precision capacitance bridge which model is QS86 (produced by Shanghai Yang Gao Electric Co. Ltd, in China). Pressure method was used in this test. The samples of about 1mm in thickness were put between the electrodes with a glass cover. A voltage of 1 kV and 50 Hz with pressure of
0.3 MPa were set. Sensitivity went up from lowest to highest level with the adjustment of the wheel in control panel. Dielectric test were carried out at the temperature of 293, 303, 313, 333, 363 K and 383 K. The records in the panel could be converted to dielectric parameter r and tan  .

sections.heading: 3.1 TEM
sections.text: TEM images of 0.5 wt% MgO/PP and 3 wt% MgO/PP are shown in Figure 2. Nano particles are uniformly located in PP. The process of surface treated could bring favorable dispersibility of nano particles in composites. Some of the particle radius in 3 wt% MgO/PP have increased compared to 0.5 wt% MgO/PP, which shows that high nano concentration appears aggregation to some extent. The results could provide a good microstructure basis for the following tests.

sections.heading: 3.2 DSC
sections.text:
Figure 3 shows the thermal behavior of nano-MgO/PP composites, the crystallization peaks of composites move right with the addition of nano-MgO, which reveals that the addition of nano-fillers improves the temperature of crystallization peaks (Tp) and the onset temperature (Tonset), while this addition reduces the semi-crystallization time (t1/2). It could be concluded that MgO plays a role of nucleating agent in composites, so it can accelerates the process of crystallization in polypropylene composite. As shown in Figure 4, the Tp of neat PP is about 382.1 K; all the samples with MgO nano-filler show an increase compared to neat PP ; The Tp of samples with nano-MgO loading of 0.5 wt% and 1 wt% are about 386.0 K and 388.6 K, respectively. Above the MgO nano-filler content of 1 or 3 wt%, the Tp of samples have a slightly decline.
Equation (1) is used to calculate the degree of crystallinity (Xc):
  0 = 1 0 0 1 m c HX w H   
 (1)
mH The melting heat of PP and MgO/PP nanocomposites
0H The melting heat of PP when PP is fully crystallized (207 J/g)
w The mass fraction of MgO in nano composites The influences of particles concentration on degree of crystallinity (Xc) are also showed in Figure 4. Enhancement of Xc can be observed with the increasing concentration of MgO particles obviously. Nano-MgO improves the velocity of crystallization and the crystalline quality of PP composite. The process of surface treated improves the dispersion effect of nano particles in composite. The regularity of arrangement of PP molecular chains would not be destroyed as the formation of crystal nucleus. Tanaka has proposed a structure to be called “interaction zones” [15]. In his hypothesis, a multi-core model was introduced as shown in Figure 5, the second layer or some ordered structure such as crystallites are created around the first layer, contributed to the fact that the second layer is very much ordered or crystallized. The existence of the interaction zone can change degree of crystallinity [16].

sections.heading: 3.3 BREAKDOWN STRENGTHS TEST
sections.text:
The theory and method of the Weibull distribution are used to analyze breakdown strengths of composites [17]. As shown in Figure 6, the scale parameter representing the breakdown voltage of 63.2 % in the Weibull probabilities can be obtained. It is observed from Table 1 that the shape parameterβ in majority of nanocomposites have an increase, which means the dispersity of breakdown strength tests in nanocomposites reduce. From Table 1 and Figure 7, the changing trends of BDs and BDs growth rate of PP and its nanocomposites could be showed clearly. The DC breakdown strength of neat PP is about 209.9 kV/mm and that of composites with 0.5 wt% nano-MgO is about 235.3 kV/mm indicating an increase of 12.1 %. The Weibull breakdown strength reaches 274.5 kV/mm with 1 wt% nano-loading, 30.8 % higher than that of neat PP. With the nano-filler more than 1 wt%, the increase of Weibull breakdown strengths comes to 22.5 % and 19.6 % for the conditions with 3 wt% nano-MgO and 6 wt% nano-MgO, respectively. It can be seen in Figure 7 that dc breakdown performance of samples with MgO is superior to neat PP in the whole investigation mass range, which means that nanofiller can improve the dc breakdown performance of PP. They exhibit best breakdown performance within 1 wt% or 3 wt% filler loading and so there may be optimal filler loading for the dielectric breakdown strength.
It is assumed that the introduction of surface-treated MgO nanoparticles into PP matrix could effectively improve breakdown strengths. This improve effect could be more significant with low concentration of nano-particle.
According to the deep trap model proposed by Tatsuo Takada [18], a trap site created by chemical defects such as conjugated carbon double bonds (C=C) or carbonyl groups (C=O) in polymer film is about 0.45 eV depth, when nano polar dielectric MgO (relative dielectric constant of εr1=9.8) ) is added into nonpolar dielectric PP(relative dielectric constant of εr2=2.3), the depth of trap will be greater than that of C=C
or C=O, and it is subjected to the applied voltage. Takada has shown the relationship between the maximum trap depth and electric field with different relative permittivity in Figure 8. According to his theory, with the breakdown electric field more than 200 kV/mm, the trapping depth in nano MgO/PP composites could exceed 3.5 eV [17], these deep trap may block the movement of carriers, bound free charge and hinder the development of breakdown path, so the BDs are improved [15].

sections.heading: 3.4 SPACE CHARGE
sections.text:
Figure 9 shows space charge behavior in PP and MgO/PP nano-composite observed under applied DC electric field of 10, 30 and 50 kV/mm for 1800 s, respectively. As shown in Figure 9a, a packet-like hetero-charge is observed in the vicinity of cathode in neat PP, and the charge amount increased with applied voltage. Compared with the neat PP, nano MgO/PP composites have a significant decline in the accumulation of space charge near cathode, only some very small hetero-charge packet appears. Cathode electrode mainly stores hetero-charge. Space charge distribution in neat PP has no marked charge accumulation near anode. With the addition of nano-MgO, some charges accumulate in the vicinity of anode. Especially for the composites with the loading of 6 wt% MgO, some homo-charge is obviously observed near anode. Impurities, which come from surface-treating process and addiction of nano-filler, could introduce some sources of space charge and lead to the appearance of some intersecting positive and negative charges [19].
To show the profiles of the electric field distributions clearly, the comparisons between PP and MgO/PP composites in electric field distortion are shown in Figure 10. The local maximum electric fields with different mass of nano-MgO under different voltage are listed in Table 2. The suppression of electric field distortion in MgO/PP nanocompostes under 10 kV/mm is not obvious. When the applied voltage reaches high, it would be clearly described that the loading of 0.5 wt%, 1 wt% and 3 wt% MgO could withstand electric field distortion as shown in Figures 10a, 10b and 10c, respectively.
Some samples have smooth electric field; their local maximum electric fields become lower than neat PP, especially when the applied voltage is high. But when the addition of nano-MgO reaches to 6 wt% in Figure 10d, the suppression of electric field distortion have deteriorated, the maximum electric fields becomes higher than neat PP as shown in Table 2.
The positive charge packet near cathode in neat PP may come from the injected charge such as holes, and these holes migrate toward the counter electrode under applied voltage. This positive charge packet is greatly decreased in MgO/PP nanocomposites [20]. According to the trapping model proposed by Takada, the addition of MgO to PP could produce deep trap, it could be figured out in Figure 8 that the trap depth of nano MgO/PP composites come to 0.6 eV and 0.9 eV with the electric field reach 30 kV/mm and 50 kV/mm, respectively [18]. The trap could capture the charges and block the movement of space charge carriers, which lead to the decrease of charge packet [21]. The weak of the carrier mobility result in the suppression of electric field distortion as it is shown in Figure 10. On the other hand, when the external electric field is 10 kV/mm, the trap depth has no increase. It may explain the nanocomposites have no much effect on the suppression of electric field distortion under 10 kV/mm. If the MgO loading exceeds a certain concentration such as 6 wt%, the impurities introduced by the addition of nanoparticles have greatly increased, some charges in the film can be considered coming from the ionization of impurities. It increases the amount of charges, and lead to more serious distortion of electric field [20].

sections.heading: 3.5 DIELECTRIC MEASUREMENT TEST
sections.text: The investigations of permittivity r and dielectric loss t a n  were carried out, respectively. Permittivity r symbolizes the molecular polarization and it is related to molecular structure, frequency of electric field, temperature and so on. Dielectric loss tan  symbolizes the electric energy that medium has consumed under alternating electric field (AEF). The chosen temperature of 293, 303 and 313 K in this test is closed to room temperature, and temperature of 333, 363 and 383 K is the simulation of heating condition caused by fault.

sections.heading: 3.5.1 PERMITTIVITY TEST
sections.text:
The influence of temperature and nano concentration on the permittivity of composites is illustrated in Figure 11 and Table 3, and two trends could be revealed. Firstly, permittivity of all samples goes up with the increasing temperature at the beginning and then declines slightly after the temperature reaches about 333 K. Secondly, it could be seen in Table 3
that most of the composites with the loading of MgO particles have a decrease in permittivity, which has been similarly reported in some literature that nano-filler loading could decrease permittivity [22-24]. When the temperature is higher than the glass transition temperature, which has been reported to be about 275.5 K in some literature [25], PP and its nanocomposites are in high elastic state, chain elements and the groups in molecule would orientate in electric field, so relaxation polarization appears and permittivity of samples increase. But when the temperature reaches high enough, thermal motions would become disordered. Directional movement would be influenced, and permittivity could have a slight decline. The decrease trend of permittivity after the addition of nano-MgO may result from the enhancement of the degree of crystallinity. This enhancement arranges its molecules in an orderly manner and intensifies the interaction between molecules. So the molecular orientation becomes difficult and the permittivity of nanocomposites decreases.

sections.heading: 3.5.2 DIELECTRIC LOSS TEST
sections.text:
It can be seen from Figure 12, dielectric loss tan of the samples are in 10-3 orders of magnitude which shows good insulation characteristic. When a low concentration of MgO is added such as 0.5 wt% and 1 wt%, dielectric loss still keep in a low level. But if the nano concentration reaches 3 wt% and 6 wt%, dielectric loss is in a higher level than PP, and it would increase with the increasing concentration of nano-MgO and the increasing temperature. Since PP is a nonpolar organic mediums, the dielectric loss tan of PP and nano MgO/PP mainly come from impurities conductivity, and it is proportional to electrical conductivity γ. The addition of nano MgO would bring impurities and increase the amount of carriers, and it causes the increase of electrical conductivity γ. This effect becomes more apparent when the concentration of MgO reaches high. Besides, the electrical conductivity γ
would increase with the temperature exponentially. So high concentration of nanofiller and high temperature could bring the increase of dielectric loss of MgO/PP composites. It shows the excellent insulation properties in nanocomposites with low nano concentration and the limitation in that with high nano concentration.

sections.heading: 3.6 DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Some significant improvements of insulating property are revealed with the addition of nano-MgO, such as the improvement in crystallization condition, the enhancement of dc BDs, the decrease of space charge accumulation, the suppression of electric distortion, the decrease of permittivity and so on. But when the concentration of nano MgO reaches high enough to 6 wt%, the effect in the suppression of the space charge and electric distortion become inconspicuous. Besides, the little drop of dc BDs and the increasing of dielectric loss appear. Insulating properties of composites have good improvements at low concentration of the nanofiller. Especially when the nanofiller remains 1 wt%, dc BDs maintain about 274.5 kV/mm and other insulating properties perform at high levels. It can be highlighted that the excellent effect of resisting space charge accumulation makes nano MgO/PP composite valuable for the materials of dc cable insulation.
PP itself has good insulation property, the deep trap caused by the addition of polar particle can limit the motion of carries in matrix resin. So the performance in BDs and space charge property improve. But when the concentration of MgO comes to a high level such as 3 wt% and 6 wt%, agglomeration of nano particles is hard to avoid as shown in Figure 2. The high concentration of particles brings more impurities inevitably, the impurities produce extra carries, and it causes some phenomenon which happens at high nano concentration such as the decline of BDs, the more serious of electric field distortion and the increase of dielectric loss ta n  .
As a new insulation material, PP has the recycling properties. The non-crosslinked processes make PP easily decomposable and bring it very high re-uses value. So the application of PP in insulation area is meaningful in energy conservation and environmental protection and it could meet the requirements of 3Rs (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle). In this study, PP and MgO/PP nanocomposites have shown excellent
electric insulating property and good prospects of application in insulation material field. The further studies would be carried out in the area of some other dielectric properties such as the measurement of resistivity and the evaluation of insulation aging, together with the research in mechanical and thermal properties.

sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
In this study, the effect of nanoparticles on the dc insulating properties in MgO/PP nanocomposites was investigated. TEM images have shown good dispersibility of surface-treated MgO in PP matrix. The experiment results are based on good microstructure foundation. The effects of nanofiller loading can be summarized as follows:
1) The loading of nano-MgO can accelerate the rate of crystallization and improve the degree of crystallinity in PP, and the increase of concentration in the nanofiller can further enhance the crystallinity of composites.
2) The introduction of nanoparticle can effectively improve dc breakdown strengths of MgO/PP composites, and low concentration of nano MgO has a better improvement effect.
3) The space charge measurements during dc endurance reveal that the addition of MgO nanofiller can decrease the amount of heterocharge near the cathode of the film compared to neat PP. Some homo and intersecting positive and negative charges appear when the concentration of nano MgO reaches high. The space charge measurements also show that the distortion of electric field in MgO/PP composites has been suppressed with the loading the nanoparticle compared to neat PP. But the effect of the suppression becomes deteriorated when the concentration of nanofiller reaches high to 6 wt%.
4) Permittivity of composites tends to increase with the rise of temperature at first and then has a slightly decrease. A little decline of permittivity is found with the addition of MgO. Dielectric loss of composites is in 10-3 orders of magnitude.
5) With the concentration of nano-MgO is low to 0.5 wt% or 1 wt%, the insulating properties of composite have a better perform comparing with the composites of other concentration.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: This work was in part financially supported by National Key Basic Research Program (973) of China (2014CB239506) to which the authors are indebted. The author also acknowledges Chinese State Energy Smart Grid R&D Center (Shanghai) to provide the experiment equipment.

He obtained the B.Sc. degrees in high voltage and insulation technology at Xi’an Jiao Tong University, China in 2013. He has doing research of dielectric properties of polymer nano-composite and electrical insulation in the Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University as a postgraduate. . metadata.abstractText: Polypropylene (PP) has special advantages in replacing conventional crosslinked polyethylene (XLPE) to be insulation material of power cable. In order to reveal the effects of nano-filler addition on PP, five kinds of experiments, namely TEM, DSC, breakdown strengths (BDs), space charge and dielectric measurement were investigated to evaluate the insulating properties of PP and its nanocomposites with surface-treated nano-MgO of different concentration. It is revealed that, with the addition of nanoMgO, favorable dispersibility of nano-filler and significant increase of crystallinity of polymer are observed. BDs under dc voltage increase apparently with loading of nano MgO, but when the nano concentration reaches higher than 1 wt%, the BDs have a slight decline compared with 1 wt%. It is clarified that space charge and electric field distortion are well restricted with the addition of nano-MgO, while this effect is not obvious with the nano concentration reaches 6 wt%. Permittivity has trends of increase with the rise of temperature at first and then decrease when the temperature reaches about 333 K, and the addition of nano-filler MgO could also decrease permittivity. When the nano-filler concentration reaches high, dielectric loss increases to a high level. Low nano-filler concentration in MgO/PP shows better electrical insulation properties compared with PP and high nano-filler concentration composites. Index Terms PP, Nano-MgO, TEM, DSC, breakdown strengths, space charge, dielectric property.
